content.text: Define _gravitational potential_ at a point
An isolated solid sphere of radius \(r\) may be assumed to have its mass \(M\) concentrated at its centre. The magnitude of the gravitational potential at the surface of the sphere is \(\phi\)
On Fig. 1.1, show the variation of the gravitational potential with distance \(d\) from the centre of the sphere for values of \(d\) from \(d = r\) to \(d = 4r\)
Calculate the change in gravitational potential energy of the rock
change =   .........  J
Explain whether the rock's speed increases, decreases or stays the same
The sphere in **(b)** is a planet with radius \(r\) of \(6.4 \times 10^{6} \text{m}\) and mass \(M\) of \(6.0 \times 10^{24} \text{kg}\). The planet has no atmosphere
A rock of mass \(3.4 \times 10^{3} \text{kg}\) moves directly towards the planet. Its distance from the centre of the planet changes from \(4r\) to \(3r\)
A square box of volume \(V\) contains \(N\) molecules of an ideal gas. Each molecule has mass \(m\)

Using the kinetic theory of ideal gases, it can be shown that, if all the molecules are moving with speed \(v\) at right angles to one face of the box, the pressure \(p\) exerted on the face of the box is given by the expression
(equation 1)
This expression leads to the formula
(equation 2)
for the pressure \(p\) of an ideal gas, where \(\rho\) is the density of the gas and \(\langle c^2\rangle\) is the mean-square speed of the molecules
Explain how each of the following terms in equation 2 is derived from equation 1:
\(\langle c^2\rangle\):
An ideal gas has volume, pressure and temperature as shown in Fig. 2.1
The mass of the gas is \(20.7 \text{g}\)
Calculate the mass of one molecule of the gas
a lump of solid lead as it melts at constant temperature
some gas in a toy balloon when the balloon bursts and no thermal energy enters or leaves the gas
By reference to the first law of thermodynamics, state and explain the change, if any, in the internal energy of:
Use Fig. 4.2 to show that the angular frequency \(\omega\) of oscillation of the ball in the dish is \(2.9 \text{rad} \text{s}^{-1}\)
determine \(R\)
calculate the speed of the ball as it passes over the centre C of the dish
Use the information in (a) to:
Some moisture collects on the surface of the dish so that the motion of the ball becomes lightly damped
On the axes of Fig. 4.2, draw a line to show the lightly damped motion of the ball for the first 5.0 s after the release of the ball
A dish is made from a section of a hollow glass sphere
The dish, fixed to a horizontal table, contains a small solid ball of mass \(45\mathrm{g}\), as shown in Fig. 4.1
The horizontal displacement of the ball from the centre C of the dish is x
Initially, the ball is held at rest with distance \(x = 3.0 \text{cm}\)
The ball is then released. The variation with time \(t\) of the horizontal displacement \(x\) of the ball from point C is shown in Fig. 4.2
The motion of the ball in the dish is simple harmonic with its acceleration a given by the expression
where \(g\) is the acceleration of free fall and \(R\) is a constant that depends on the dimensions of the dish and the ball
Explain the principles of the **detection** of ultrasound waves for medical diagnosis
By reference to specific acoustic impedance, explain why there is very little transmission of ultrasound waves from air into skin
Telephone signals may be transmitted either by means of an optic fibre or by means of a wire pair
State **three** advantages of the use of an optic fibre rather than a wire pair
the power of the background noise
the maximum attenuation per unit length of the optic fibre that allows for uninterrupted transmission of the signal
attenuation per unit length =   .........  dB km\(^{-1}\)
It is proposed to transmit a signal over a distance of \(4.5 \times 10^{3} \text{km}\) by means of an optic fibre
The input signal has a power of \(9.8 \text{mW}\)
The minimum signal that can be detected at the output has a power of \(6.3 \times 10^{-17} \text{W}\). For this signal power, the signal-to-noise ratio is \(21 \text{dB}\)
Calculate:
State what is meant by electric field strength
Use Fig. 7.2 to determine the radius \(R\) of the sphere. Explain your working
Use Fig. 7.2 to determine the charge \(Q\) on the sphere
An \(\alpha\)-particle is situated a distance \(8.0 \text{cm}\) from the centre of the sphere
Calculate the acceleration of the \(\alpha\)-particle
acceleration =   .........  \(m s^{-2}\)
A metal sphere of radius \(R\) is isolated in space
Point P is a distance \(\mathbf{x}\) from the centre of the sphere, as illustrated in Fig. 7.1
The variation with distance \(\mathbf{x}\) of the electric field strength \(E\) due to the charge on the sphere is shown in Fig. 7.2
what is meant by infinite bandwidth
the effect, if any, on the output voltage of increasing the load resistance
An ideal operational amplifier (op-amp) is connected to a load resistor
The op-amp is assumed to have infinite bandwidth and zero output resistance
State:
Explain why point P is known as a virtual earth
Calculate the potential at point Q
potential =   .........  V
At a temperature of \(13^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\), the resistance of the thermistor T is \(230\mathrm{k}\Omega\)
Show that the potential difference measured with the voltmeter is \(0.88\mathrm{V}\)
A student designs the circuit shown in Fig. 8.1 in order to indicate changes in temperature of the thermistor T
The resistance of the thermistor T in **(b)** decreases as its temperature rises
Explain the effect of this change in temperature on the potential difference measured with the voltmeter
State and explain the direction of the magnetic field
Show that the speed \(v\) of the electron is \(9.0 \times 10^{6} \text{m s}^{- 1}\)

An electron is travelling at speed \(v\) in a straight line in a vacuum. It enters a uniform magnetic field of flux density \(8.0 \times 10^{- 4} \text{T}\). Initially, the electron is travelling at right angles to the magnetic field, as illustrated in Fig. 9.1
The path of the electron in the magnetic field is an arc of a circle of radius \(6.4 \text{cm}\)
On Fig. 9.2, mark with an arrow the direction of the uniform electric field
Use data from (a) to calculate the magnitude of the electric field strength
field strength =   .........  \(NC^{-1}\)
A uniform electric field is now applied in the same region as the magnetic field
The electron passes undeviated through the region of the two fields, as illustrated in Fig. 9.2
The electron in (b) is now replaced by an \(\alpha\) -particle travelling at the same speed \(v\) along the same initial path as the electron
Describe and explain the shape of the path in the region of the magnetic and electric fields
State Faraday's law of electromagnetic induction
State one function of a transformer
A sinusoidal alternating current in the primary coil gives rise to a varying magnetic flux linking the secondary coil
Use Faraday's law to explain why the output from the transformer is an electromotive force (e.m.f.) that is alternating
State why the soft-iron core of the transformer is laminated
A simple iron-cored transformer is illustrated in Fig. 10.1
The uppermost energy bands in a solid are known as the valence band (VB), the forbidden band (FB) and the conduction band (CB)
A copper wire is at room temperature
Use band theory to explain why the resistance of the copper wire increases as its temperature increases
The structure of a copper crystal is to be examined using electron diffraction
Electrons, having been accelerated from rest through a potential difference \(V,\) are incident on the crystal
The de Broglie wavelength \(\lambda\) of the electrons is \(2.6 \times 10^{- 11} \text{m}\)
Calculate the accelerating potential difference \(V.\)
State what is meant by the mass defect of a nucleus
the energy equivalence of 1.00 u is 934 MeV
the binding energy per nucleon of a helium-4 nucleus is 7.09 MeV
Some masses are shown in Table 12.1
Show that:
Isotopes of hydrogen have binding energies per nucleon of less than 3 MeV
Suggest why a nucleus of helium-4 does not spontaneously break down to become nuclei of hydrogen
